entries.content: To bounce or render tracks in REAPER: Select the tracks you want to bounce. Go to File > Render or press Ctrl+Alt+R. Choose 'Stems (selected tracks)' from the Source dropdown. Set your format (WAV recommended for quality). Choose 'Add rendered items to project' if you want to keep working. Click Render. The bounced audio will appear as new items.
tips: Use 'Render to project' for quick bouncing
Mute original tracks after bouncing to save CPU
Consider freezing tracks instead for reversible bounce

entries.content: Freezing tracks is a reversible way to bounce: Right-click the track and select 'Freeze track' or 'Render/Freeze > Freeze to stereo'. This renders all FX and items to audio, freeing CPU. To unfreeze later, right-click and select 'Unfreeze'. Frozen tracks show a snowflake icon.
steps: Select 'Freeze track' or use Track menu
tips: Freeze heavy plugin chains during mixing
Unfreeze to make edits, re-freeze when done

entries.content: Quick render to a new track: Select items or time range. Go to File > Render or Ctrl+Alt+R. Under Source, choose your selection. Enable 'Add rendered items to new tracks in project'. Set your format. This creates a new track with the rendered audio while keeping originals.

To export your final mix: File > Render (Ctrl+Alt+R). Source: Master mix. Set format (WAV for master, MP3/M4A for distribution). Choose sample rate (44.1kHz for CD, 48kHz for video). Bit depth 24-bit or 16-bit. Enable 'Normalize/Limit' if needed. Click Render.

Time stretching in REAPER: Hold Alt and drag the right edge of an item to stretch/compress time. The item changes length without changing pitch. REAPER uses élastique by default for high-quality stretching. For better control, right-click item > Item properties > Playback rate.
tips: Use 'Preserve pitch when changing rate' in item settings
élastique Pro is best for complex audio

entries.content: To change pitch without changing tempo: Select item > Item properties. Enable 'Preserve pitch when changing rate'. Or use ReaPitch plugin for real-time pitch shifting. For pitch envelope: right-click item > Take > Take pitch envelope. You can automate pitch changes over time.
tips: Small shifts (±2 semitones) sound most natural
Pitch envelope great for risers and drops

entries.content: Match audio to project tempo: Right-click item > Item processing > Set item tempo from... Choose source tempo or tap it. Item will stretch to match project tempo. For loops, use 'Set item timebase to beats'. Now the loop follows tempo changes automatically.

For precise timing correction: Double-click item to open in editor. Enable 'Show stretch markers'. Alt+click to add stretch markers at transients. Drag markers to align timing. Great for tightening drums or fixing timing issues.
tips: Use at transient points for best results
Less is more - too many markers can cause artifacts

entries.content: Recording multiple tracks simultaneously: Create tracks for each input (Ctrl+T). On each track, click the input dropdown and assign unique inputs (Input 1, Input 2, etc.). Arm all tracks for recording (select all, press R or click arm buttons). Press Record to capture all inputs at once.
steps: Assign unique inputs to each track
tips: Set input levels to avoid clipping

entries.content: Setting up for full band recording: Create tracks: Kick, Snare, Overheads, Bass, Guitar L, Guitar R, Vocals. Route interface inputs to corresponding tracks. Create headphone submix for performers. Enable input monitoring on each track. Set up click track on separate output.

Hear yourself while recording: Click the speaker icon on track (or press I with track selected). This routes input through REAPER. For lower latency, use direct monitoring from your interface instead. To disable auto-monitoring: Preferences > Audio > Auto-mute input when stopped.

Create separate mixes for performers: Add a new track as 'Headphone Bus'. Route instrument tracks to this bus via sends. Adjust send levels for performer's preferred mix. Route Headphone Bus to a separate interface output. Connect headphone amp to that output.
tips: Performers usually want more of themselves
Include click track in cue mix
Keep latency low for live monitoring

entries.content: Save your setup as a template: Set up tracks, routing, FX, and settings as desired. File > Project templates > Save project as template. Name it descriptively (e.g., 'Rock Band Session'). Access via File > Project templates. Templates include tracks, FX, routing, tempo, and time signature.

Save individual track setups: Set up a track with FX, routing, etc. Right-click track > Save tracks as track template. Name it (e.g., 'Vocal Chain'). Insert later via Track > Insert track from template. Great for reusing your go-to channel strips.

Save and recall FX chains: Open FX window on track. Click the + button or 'FX' dropdown. Select 'Save FX chain as...' to save. To load: 'Load FX chain...' Your chain appears in the FX browser under 'FX Chains'.
tips: Include both insert and parallel chains

entries.content: Save window layouts as screensets: Arrange windows as desired. Press Ctrl+1 through Ctrl+9 to save current layout. Press 1-9 (without Ctrl) to recall. Great for switching between recording, editing, and mixing views.

Set your default new project: Create project with your preferred settings. File > Project templates > Save project as template. Check 'Make default project' or name it exactly 'default'. New projects will use this setup. Include tempo, sample rate, tracks, and routing.

Set up count-in before recording: Options > Pre-roll before recording. Set number of measures (usually 1-2). Enable metronome for count-in. Now recording will play back the pre-roll section before punch point, giving you time to prepare.

Record only within a specific range: Set time selection over the section to re-record. Options > Auto-punch. Press Record - playback starts before selection, records only within it, continues playing after. Perfect for fixing sections without re-recording everything.

Record multiple takes and choose the best: Enable loop mode. Record multiple passes - each creates a new take. Expand take lanes (click lane header). Click on sections to select best parts from each take. REAPER creates crossfades automatically. Right-click > Crop to active take when done.
tips: Use 'Explode takes to tracks' for parallel editing

entries.content: REAPER has several recording modes: Normal (item) - creates new items. Overdub - layers on existing items. Replace - overwrites existing audio. Time selection auto-punch - only records in selection. Tape mode - destructive replace. Access via right-click on record button.

modes.Overdub: Layers takes, good for building parts

entries.content: Automate any parameter: Click the Trim/Envelopes button on track (or press V). Select parameter to automate. Draw automation with pencil tool or record it. For real-time: enable Write mode, press Play, move the control. Points are recorded as you adjust.

modes.Touch: Writes when touched, returns when released

entries.content: Automate track volume for dynamics: Show volume envelope (V on track). Click to add points, drag to adjust. Use 4-point technique for fades: start level, transition start, transition end, end level. Hold Shift for finer control.
tips: Use trim envelope for overall adjustments

entries.content: Automate plugin parameters: Open plugin, click 'Param' button. Select 'FX Parameter List'. Choose parameter and click 'Learn' while moving it. Or enable 'UI' button to show all automatable params. Create envelope and draw automation.

Shape automation with curves: Right-click between points for curve options. Linear = straight line. Fast start = quick change then slow. Fast end = slow then quick. Bezier = S-curve. Smooth = gentle curves. Hold Alt while dragging for custom curves.

Add effects to tracks: Click FX button on track (or press F with track selected). Browse effects by category or search. Double-click to add. Drag to reorder in chain. Click bypass button to A/B. Right-click for more options.

Run effects in parallel: Create send to new track. Add effects on the send track. Blend dry (original) with wet (effected). Great for parallel compression, reverb, and creative effects. Use pre-fader sends for consistent wet level.

REAPER includes excellent free plugins: ReaEQ - flexible parametric EQ. ReaComp - versatile compressor. ReaDelay - delay with sync. ReaVerb - convolution reverb. ReaGate - noise gate. ReaPitch - pitch shifting. ReaLimit - brick-wall limiter. All low CPU and high quality.

Proper gain staging in REAPER: Aim for -18dBFS to -12dBFS on individual tracks for optimal headroom. Use the track trim/gain before the fader for initial level setting. Keep the master fader at 0dB and adjust individual tracks instead. Watch for red meters indicating clipping.
tips: Set input gain so peaks hit around -12dB
Use VU meters for average levels

entries.content: EQ tips for mixing: Cut before boost - remove unwanted frequencies before adding. High-pass filter vocals around 80-100Hz to remove rumble. Cut muddy frequencies around 200-400Hz. Boost presence in vocals around 3-5kHz. Use narrow Q for cutting, wide Q for boosting.
tips: High-pass everything except bass and kick

entries.content: Compression settings guide: For vocals use 3:1 to 4:1 ratio, medium attack (10-30ms), medium release. For drums use faster attack, 4:1 to 8:1 ratio. For bass use slower attack to preserve transients. Aim for 3-6dB of gain reduction on most sources.
tips: Use makeup gain to match levels

entries.content: Reverb tips: Use sends instead of inserts for reverb. Pre-delay of 20-40ms helps clarity. Short reverb (0.5-1s) for intimate, long reverb (2-4s) for epic. Roll off low frequencies on reverb returns. Delay times: 1/4 note, 1/8 note, or sync to tempo.
tips: Send to reverb bus, don't insert on tracks
Use pre-delay to separate dry signal

entries.content: Panning strategies: Keep bass, kick, snare, and lead vocals centered. Pan guitars left and right (hard pan or 50-70%). Double-tracked parts should be panned opposite. Use LCR (Left-Center-Right) panning for clarity. Pan background vocals wide.

Setting up recording in REAPER: Go to track, click input dropdown to select audio input. Enable record arm (R button). Enable input monitoring to hear yourself. Set buffer size lower (128-256) for less latency during recording. Use direct monitoring from interface if latency is an issue.

Punch-in recording: Set time selection over the section to re-record. Enable 'Auto-punch' in transport. Press record - it will only record within the selection. Use pre-roll to hear context before punch point. Alt+click on timeline for quick time selection.

Loop recording for multiple takes: Set loop points with time selection. Enable loop in transport. Record multiple passes - REAPER creates take lanes. Use Ctrl+click to audition different takes. Right-click take lane to comp best parts.

REAPER recording modes: Normal mode - record to new items. Overdub mode - layer on top of existing. Replace mode - replace existing audio. Time selection auto-punch - only record in selection. Use Options menu to change recording behavior.

Essential editing operations: S = split item at cursor. Delete = remove selected item. Ctrl+C/V = copy/paste. G = glue items. Ctrl+Z = undo (unlimited). Hold Shift while dragging for snapping. Double-click item to open in editor.

Ripple editing modes: Off - items don't move when you delete. Per-track - only items on same track shift. All tracks - all items after edit point shift. Toggle with Alt+Shift+R or button in toolbar. Essential for podcast/dialog editing.

Working with time selection: Click+drag on timeline to select time. Ctrl+Shift+click for precise selection. Tab to move between transients. Shift+Tab for previous transient. Use time selection for rendering, exporting, or operations.

Comping multiple takes: Record in loop mode to create take lanes. Click on take lane header to expand. Click sections to select best parts from each take. Right-click for 'Crop to active take'. Use Ctrl+L to show lanes.

Creating fades: Drag from top corners of item for fade in/out. Select items and press X for auto-crossfade. Double-click fade to edit curve. S-curve for smooth, Linear for quick. Set default fade length in preferences.

Creating sends: Click track routing button (Route). Add new send to destination track. Adjust send level with fader. Pre-fader send = level independent of track fader. Post-fader = follows track fader. Create bus tracks for group processing.
tips: Use sends for reverb and delay
Create drum bus for parallel compression

entries.content: Setting up sidechain: Add compressor to track (e.g., bass). In compressor, click sidechain input. Route from trigger track (e.g., kick) to compressor sidechain. Adjust compressor threshold and ratio. Classic use: duck bass when kick hits.
tips: Sidechain bass to kick for punch
Sidechain pads to vocals for clarity
Use sidechain on reverb for cleaner mix

entries.content: Using folder tracks: Right-click track > Insert folder. Drag tracks into folder. Folder track acts as submix bus. Apply processing to folder to affect all children. Collapse/expand with folder icon. Great for drum groups, vocal stacks.

Routing to hardware: Master track routes to hardware outputs by default. For multiple outputs, use track routing. Create headphone mix on separate output. Use hardware output for external effects sends. Check I/O button in mixer.
tips: Create separate cue mixes for musicians

solutions: Check track is not muted or soloed incorrectly
Check routing - is track routed to master?
Check audio device in Preferences > Audio > Device
Check master fader is not down
Verify audio interface is selected and working
Lower buffer size in Preferences > Audio > Device
Use ASIO driver on Windows, Core Audio on Mac
Disable high-latency plugins during recording
Use direct monitoring from your interface
Increase buffer for mixing when latency doesn't matter
Freeze tracks with heavy plugins
Increase buffer size
Use track templates to reduce plugin count
Enable anticipative FX processing
Bounce/render CPU-heavy tracks
Increase audio buffer size
Check for driver conflicts
Disable Wi-Fi and Bluetooth
Close other applications
Check for sample rate mismatches
Make sure track is armed (red button)
Check input is selected on track
Verify input levels in mixer
Check microphone permissions (Mac)
Ensure correct input device in preferences

entries.tip: Use screensets to save window layouts. Press numbers 1-9 to recall, Ctrl+1-9 to save.
Double-click on a fader to reset it to 0dB/center.
Hold Ctrl while dragging for fine adjustment of any control.
Use track templates to save your favorite channel strip setups.
Press Tab to move to next transient, great for navigating drums.
Use SWS extension for powerful additional features like snapshots and notes.
Create a template project with your usual track layout and routing.
Use relative mouse mode in preferences for smoother fader control.
Color code your tracks - right click track > Track color.
Use track folders to organize and submix related tracks.
